verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah said, “God has brought me laughter, and everyone who hears about this will laugh with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And she added, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The child grew and was weaned, and on the day Isaac was weaned Abraham held a great feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Sarah saw that the son whom Hagar the Egyptian had borne to Abraham was mocking,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and she said to Abraham, “Get rid of that slave woman and her son, for that woman’s son will never share in the inheritance with my son Isaac.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The matter distressed Abraham greatly because it concerned his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God said to him, “Do not be so distressed about the boy and your slave woman. Listen to whatever Sarah tells you, because it is through Isaac that your offspring will be reckoned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make the son of the slave into a nation also, because he is your offspring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning Abraham took some food and a skin of water and gave them to Hagar. He set them on her shoulders and then sent her off with the boy. She went on her way and wandered in the Desert of Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the water in the skin was gone, she put the boy under one of the bushes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she went off and sat down about a bowshot away, for she thought, “I cannot watch the boy die.” And as she sat there, she began to sob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God heard the boy crying, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and said to her, “What is the matter, Hagar? Do not be afraid; God has heard the boy crying as he lies there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lift the boy up and take him by the hand, for I will make him into a great nation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God opened her eyes and she saw a well of water. So she went and filled the skin with water and gave the boy a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God was with the boy as he grew up. He lived in the desert and became an archer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was living in the Desert of Paran, his mother got a wife for him from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Abimelek and Phicol the commander of his forces said to Abraham, “God is with you in everything you do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now swear to me here before God that you will not deal falsely with me or my children or my descendants. Show to me and the country where you now reside as a foreigner the same kindness I have shown to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “I swear it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham complained to Abimelek about a well of water that Abimelek’s servants had seized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abimelek said, “I don’t know who has done this. You did not tell me, and I heard about it only today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham brought sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelek, and the two men made a treaty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham set apart seven ewe lambs from the flock,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Abimelek asked Abraham, “What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs you have set apart by themselves?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “Accept these seven lambs from my hand as a witness that I dug this well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that place was called Beersheba, because the two men swore an oath there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the treaty had been made at Beersheba, Abimelek and Phicol the commander of his forces returned to the land of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba, and there he called on the name of the Lord, the Eternal God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some time later God tested Abraham. He said to him, “Abraham!”
“Here I am,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said, “Take your son, your only son, whom you love—Isaac—and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on a mountain I will show you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning Abraham got up and loaded his donkey. He took with him two of his servants and his son Isaac. When he had cut enough wood for the burnt offering, he set out for the place God had told him about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his servants, “Stay here with the donkey while I and the boy go over there. We will worship and then we will come back to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and placed it on his son Isaac, and he himself carried the fire and the knife. As the two of them went on together,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac spoke up and said to his father Abraham, “Father?”
“Yes, my son?” Abraham replied.
“The fire and wood are here,” Isaac said, “but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham answered, “God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son.” And the two of them went on together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they reached the place God had told him about, Abraham built an altar there and arranged the wood on it. He bound his son Isaac and laid him on the altar, on top of the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he reached out his hand and took the knife to slay his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the angel of the Lord called out to him from heaven, “Abraham! Abraham!”
“Here I am,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not lay a hand on the boy,” he said. “Do not do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, because you have not withheld from me your son, your only son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham looked up and there in a thicket he saw a ram caught by its horns. He went over and took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering instead of his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham called that place The Lord Will Provide. And to this day it is said, “On the mountain of the Lord it will be provided.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of the Lord called to Abraham from heaven a second time
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, “I swear by myself, declares the Lord, that because you have done this and have not withheld your son, your only son,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will surely bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and as the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the cities of their enemies,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and through your offspring all nations on earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham returned to his servants, and they set off together for Beersheba. And Abraham stayed in Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later Abraham was told, “Milkah is also a mother; she has borne sons to your brother Nahor:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uz the firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel (the father of Aram),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph and Bethuel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milkah bore these eight sons to Abraham’s brother Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also had sons: Tebah, Gaham, Tahash and Maakah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah lived to be a hundred and twenty-seven years old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She died at Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan, and Abraham went to mourn for Sarah and to weep over her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham rose from beside his dead wife and spoke to the Hittites. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am a foreigner and stranger among you. Sell me some property for a burial site here so I can bury my dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Hittites replied to Abraham,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sir, listen to us. You are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our tombs. None of us will refuse you his tomb for burying your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham rose and bowed down before the people of the land, the Hittites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “If you are willing to let me bury my dead, then listen to me and intercede with Ephron son of Zohar on my behalf
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he will sell me the cave of Machpelah, which belongs to him and is at the end of his field. Ask him to sell it to me for the full price as a burial site among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ephron the Hittite was sitting among his people and he replied to Abraham in the hearing of all the Hittites who had come to the gate of his city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, my lord,” he said. “Listen to me; I give you the field, and I give you the cave that is in it. I give it to you in the presence of my people. Bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again Abraham bowed down before the people of the land
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said to Ephron in their hearing, “Listen to me, if you will. I will pay the price of the field. Accept it from me so I can bury my dead there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ephron answered Abraham,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen to me, my lord; the land is worth four hundred shekels of silver, but what is that between you and me? Bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham agreed to Ephron’s terms and weighed out for him the price he had named in the hearing of the Hittites: four hundred shekels of silver, according to the weight current among the merchants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah near Mamre—both the field and the cave in it, and all the trees within the borders of the field—was deeded
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to Abraham as his property in the presence of all the Hittites who had come to the gate of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah near Mamre (which is at Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the field and the cave in it were deeded to Abraham by the Hittites as a burial site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was now very old, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the senior servant in his household, the one in charge of all that he had, “Put your hand under my thigh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I want you to swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but will go to my country and my own relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant asked him, “What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Shall I then take your son back to the country you came from?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Make sure that you do not take my son back there,” Abraham said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord, the God of heaven, who brought me out of my father’s household and my native land and who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, ‘To your offspring I will give this land’—he will send his angel before you so that you can get a wife for my son from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Only do not take my son back there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the servant left, taking with him ten of his master’s camels loaded with all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time the women go out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he prayed, “Lord, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today, and show kindness to my master Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I am standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May it be that when I say to a young woman, ‘Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,’ and she says, ‘Drink, and I’ll water your camels too’—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before he had finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milkah, who was the wife of Abraham’s brother Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant hurried to meet her and said, “Please give me a little water from your jar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Drink, my lord,” she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After she had given him a drink, she said, “I’ll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Without saying a word, the man watched her closely to learn whether or not the Lord had made his journey successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a beka and two gold bracelets weighing ten shekels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he asked, “Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father’s house for us to spend the night?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She answered him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son that Milkah bore to Nahor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And she added, “We have plenty of straw and fodder, as well as room for you to spend the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man bowed down and worshiped the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, “Praise be to the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not abandoned his kindness and faithfulness to my master. As for me, the Lord has led me on the journey to the house of my master’s relatives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young woman ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and he hurried out to the man at the spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had seen the nose ring, and the bracelets on his sister’s arms, and had heard Rebekah tell what the man said to her, he went out to the man and found him standing by the camels near the spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come, you who are blessed by the Lord,” he said. “Why are you standing out here? I have prepared the house and a place for the camels.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the man went to the house, and the camels were unloaded. Straw and fodder were brought for the camels, and water for him and his men to wash their feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then food was set before him, but he said, “I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say.”
“Then tell us,” Laban said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said, “I am Abraham’s servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has blessed my master abundantly, and he has become wealthy. He has given him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My master’s wife Sarah has borne him a son in her old age, and he has given him everything he owns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And my master made me swear an oath, and said, ‘You must not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I live,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but go to my father’s family and to my own clan, and get a wife for my son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I asked my master, ‘What if the woman will not come back with me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He replied, ‘The Lord, before whom I have walked faithfully, will send his angel with you and make your journey a success, so that you can get a wife for my son from my own clan and from my father’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be released from my oath if, when you go to my clan, they refuse to give her to you—then you will be released from my oath.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When I came to the spring today, I said, ‘Lord, God of my master Abraham, if you will, please grant success to the journey on which I have come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I am standing beside this spring. If a young woman comes out to draw water and I say to her, “Please let me drink a little water from your jar,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if she says to me, “Drink, and I’ll draw water for your camels too,” let her be the one the Lord has chosen for my master’s son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Before I finished praying in my heart, Rebekah came out, with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water, and I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “She quickly lowered her jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I’ll water your camels too.’ So I drank, and she watered the camels also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’
“She said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel son of Nahor, whom Milkah bore to him.’
“Then I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her arms,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I bowed down and worshiped the Lord. I praised the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me on the right road to get the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you will show kindness and faithfulness to my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so I may know which way to turn.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban and Bethuel answered, “This is from the Lord; we can say nothing to you one way or the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is Rebekah; take her and go, and let her become the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has directed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abraham’s servant heard what they said, he bowed down to the ground before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the servant brought out gold and silver jewelry and articles of clothing and gave them to Rebekah; he also gave costly gifts to her brother and to her mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank and spent the night there.
When they got up the next morning, he said, “Send me on my way to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But her brother and her mother replied, “Let the young woman remain with us ten days or so; then you may go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said to them, “Do not detain me, now that the Lord has granted success to my journey. Send me on my way so I may go to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “Let’s call the young woman and ask her about it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they called Rebekah and asked her, “Will you go with this man?”
“I will go,” she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent their sister Rebekah on her way, along with her nurse and Abraham’s servant and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And they blessed Rebekah and said to her,
“Our sister, may you increase
    to thousands upon thousands;
may your offspring possess
    the cities of their enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah and her attendants got ready and mounted the camels and went back with the man. So the servant took Rebekah and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Isaac had come from Beer Lahai Roi, for he was living in the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went out to the field one evening to meditate, and as he looked up, he saw camels approaching.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah also looked up and saw Isaac. She got down from her camel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and asked the servant, “Who is that man in the field coming to meet us?”
“He is my master,” the servant answered. So she took her veil and covered herself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the servant told Isaac all he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac brought her into the tent of his mother Sarah, and he married Rebekah. So she became his wife, and he loved her; and Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham had taken another wife, whose name was Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak and Shuah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan; the descendants of Dedan were the Ashurites, the Letushites and the Leummites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanok, Abida and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham left everything he owned to Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while he was still living, he gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them away from his son Isaac to the land of the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham lived a hundred and seventy-five years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man and full of years; and he was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah near Mamre, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the field Abraham had bought from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac, who then lived near Beer Lahai Roi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the family line of Abraham’s son Ishmael, whom Sarah’s slave, Hagar the Egyptian, bore to Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, listed in the order of their birth: Nebaioth the firstborn of Ishmael, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish and Kedemah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Ishmael, and these are the names of the twelve tribal rulers according to their settlements and camps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael lived a hundred and thirty-seven years. He breathed his last and died, and he was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His descendants settled in the area from Havilah to Shur, near the eastern border of Egypt, as you go toward Ashur. And they lived in hostility toward all the tribes related to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of the family line of Abraham’s son Isaac.
Abraham became the father of Isaac,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan Aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac prayed to the Lord on behalf of his wife, because she was childless. The Lord answered his prayer, and his wife Rebekah became pregnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The babies jostled each other within her, and she said, “Why is this happening to me?” So she went to inquire of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to her,
“Two nations are in your womb,
    and two peoples from within you will be separated;
one people will be stronger than the other,
    and the older will serve the younger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time came for her to give birth, there were twin boys in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first to come out was red, and his whole body was like a hairy garment; so they named him Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, his brother came out, with his hand grasping Esau’s heel; so he was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when Rebekah gave birth to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boys grew up, and Esau became a skillful hunter, a man of the open country, while Jacob was content to stay at home among the tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac, who had a taste for wild game, loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once when Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau came in from the open country, famished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to Jacob, “Quick, let me have some of that red stew! I’m famished!” (That is why he was also called Edom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob replied, “First sell me your birthright.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, I am about to die,” Esau said. “What good is the birthright to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob said, “Swear to me first.” So he swore an oath to him, selling his birthright to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and some lentil stew. He ate and drank, and then got up and left.
So Esau despised his birthright.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a famine in the land—besides the previous famine in Abraham’s time—and Isaac went to Abimelek king of the Philistines in Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt; live in the land where I tell you to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay in this land for a while, and I will be with you and will bless you. For to you and your descendants I will give all these lands and will confirm the oath I swore to your father Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and will give them all these lands, and through your offspring all nations on earth will be blessed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because Abraham obeyed me and did everything I required of him, keeping my commands, my decrees and my instructions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac stayed in Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he said, “She is my sister,” because he was afraid to say, “She is my wife.” He thought, “The men of this place might kill me on account of Rebekah, because she is beautiful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Isaac had been there a long time, Abimelek king of the Philistines looked down from a window and saw Isaac caressing his wife Rebekah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Abimelek summoned Isaac and said, “She is really your wife! Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?”
Isaac answered him, “Because I thought I might lose my life on account of her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelek said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the men might well have slept with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abimelek gave orders to all the people: “Anyone who harms this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac planted crops in that land and the same year reaped a hundredfold, because the Lord blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man became rich, and his wealth continued to grow until he became very wealthy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had so many flocks and herds and servants that the Philistines envied him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the wells that his father’s servants had dug in the time of his father Abraham, the Philistines stopped up, filling them with earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelek said to Isaac, “Move away from us; you have become too powerful for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac moved away from there and encamped in the Valley of Gerar, where he settled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac reopened the wells that had been dug in the time of his father Abraham, which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham died, and he gave them the same names his father had given them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and discovered a well of fresh water there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the herders of Gerar quarreled with those of Isaac and said, “The water is ours!” So he named the well Esek, because they disputed with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they dug another well, but they quarreled over that one also; so he named it Sitnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He moved on from there and dug another well, and no one quarreled over it. He named it Rehoboth, saying, “Now the Lord has given us room and we will flourish in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there he went up to Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Do not be afraid, for I am with you; I will bless you and will increase the number of your descendants for the sake of my servant Abraham.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac built an altar there and called on the name of the Lord. There he pitched his tent, and there his servants dug a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Abimelek had come to him from Gerar, with Ahuzzath his personal adviser and Phicol the commander of his forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac asked them, “Why have you come to me, since you were hostile to me and sent me away?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “We saw clearly that the Lord was with you; so we said, ‘There ought to be a sworn agreement between us’—between us and you. Let us make a treaty with you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you will do us no harm, just as we did not harm you but always treated you well and sent you away peacefully. And now you are blessed by the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac then made a feast for them, and they ate and drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning the men swore an oath to each other. Then Isaac sent them on their way, and they went away peacefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug. They said, “We’ve found water!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called it Shibah, and to this day the name of the town has been Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and also Basemath daughter of Elon the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were a source of grief to Isaac and Rebekah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could no longer see, he called for Esau his older son and said to him, “My son.”
“Here I am,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said, “I am now an old man and don’t know the day of my death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, get your equipment—your quiver and bow—and go out to the open country to hunt some wild game for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Prepare me the kind of tasty food I like and bring it to me to eat, so that I may give you my blessing before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rebekah was listening as Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau left for the open country to hunt game and bring it back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “Look, I overheard your father say to your brother Esau,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Bring me some game and prepare me some tasty food to eat, so that I may give you my blessing in the presence of the Lord before I die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, my son, listen carefully and do what I tell you:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may give you his blessing before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, “But my brother Esau is a hairy man while I have smooth skin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What if my father touches me? I would appear to be tricking him and would bring down a curse on myself rather than a blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mother said to him, “My son, let the curse fall on me. Just do what I say; go and get them for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared some tasty food, just the way his father liked it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah took the best clothes of Esau her older son, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goatskins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she handed to her son Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He went to his father and said, “My father.”
“Yes, my son,” he answered. “Who is it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac asked his son, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?”
“The Lord your God gave me success,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob went close to his father Isaac, who touched him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he proceeded to bless him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Are you really my son Esau?” he asked.
“I am,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said, “My son, bring me some of your game to eat, so that I may give you my blessing.”
Jacob brought it to him and he ate; and he brought some wine and he drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come here, my son, and kiss me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he blessed him and said,
“Ah, the smell of my son
    is like the smell of a field
    that the Lord has blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May God give you heaven’s dew
    and earth’s richness—
    an abundance of grain and new wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May nations serve you
    and peoples bow down to you.
Be lord over your brothers,
    and may the sons of your mother bow down to you.
May those who curse you be cursed
    and those who bless you be blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Isaac finished blessing him, and Jacob had scarcely left his father’s presence, his brother Esau came in from hunting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He too prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. Then he said to him, “My father, please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His father Isaac asked him, “Who are you?”
“I am your son,” he answered, “your firstborn, Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me? I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau heard his father’s words, he burst out with a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me—me too, my father!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said, “Isn’t he rightly named Jacob? This is the second time he has taken advantage of me: He took my birthright, and now he’s taken my blessing!” Then he asked, “Haven’t you reserved any blessing for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!” Then Esau wept aloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His father Isaac answered him,
“Your dwelling will be
    away from the earth’s richness,
    away from the dew of heaven above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will live by the sword
    and you will serve your brother.
But when you grow restless,
    you will throw his yoke
    from off your neck.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. He said to himself, “The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rebekah was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother Esau is planning to avenge himself by killing you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, my son, do what I say: Flee at once to my brother Laban in Harran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay with him for a while until your brother’s fury subsides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your brother is no longer angry with you and forgets what you did to him, I’ll send word for you to come back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I’m disgusted with living because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a wife from among the women of this land, from Hittite women like these, my life will not be worth living.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac called for Jacob and blessed him. Then he commanded him: “Do not marry a Canaanite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go at once to Paddan Aram, to the house of your mother’s father Bethuel. Take a wife for yourself there, from among the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and increase your numbers until you become a community of peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he give you and your descendants the blessing given to Abraham, so that you may take possession of the land where you now reside as a foreigner, the land God gave to Abraham.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac sent Jacob on his way, and he went to Paddan Aram, to Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, who was the mother of Jacob and Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Esau learned that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had sent him to Paddan Aram to take a wife from there, and that when he blessed him he commanded him, “Do not marry a Canaanite woman,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother and had gone to Paddan Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau then realized how displeasing the Canaanite women were to his father Isaac;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he went to Ishmael and married Mahalath, the sister of Nebaioth and daughter of Ishmael son of Abraham, in addition to the wives he already had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob left Beersheba and set out for Harran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he reached a certain place, he stopped for the night because the sun had set. Taking one of the stones there, he put it under his head and lay down to sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a dream in which he saw a stairway resting on the earth, with its top reaching to heaven, and the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There above it stood the Lord, and he said: “I am the Lord, the God of your father Abraham and the God of Isaac. I will give you and your descendants the land on which you are lying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west and to the east, to the north and to the south. All peoples on earth will be blessed through you and your offspring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he thought, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God; this is the gate of heaven.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning Jacob took the stone he had placed under his head and set it up as a pillar and poured oil on top of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called that place Bethel, though the city used to be called Luz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob made a vow, saying, “If God will be with me and will watch over me on this journey I am taking and will give me food to eat and clothes to wear
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that I return safely to my father’s household, then the Lord will be my God
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and this stone that I have set up as a pillar will be God’s house, and of all that you give me I will give you a tenth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob continued on his journey and came to the land of the eastern peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he saw a well in the open country, with three flocks of sheep lying near it because the flocks were watered from that well. The stone over the mouth of the well was large.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds would roll the stone away from the well’s mouth and water the sheep. Then they would return the stone to its place over the mouth of the well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob asked the shepherds, “My brothers, where are you from?”
“We’re from Harran,” they replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to them, “Do you know Laban, Nahor’s grandson?”
“Yes, we know him,” they answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Jacob asked them, “Is he well?”
“Yes, he is,” they said, “and here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look,” he said, “the sun is still high; it is not time for the flocks to be gathered. Water the sheep and take them back to pasture.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We can’t,” they replied, “until all the flocks are gathered and the stone has been rolled away from the mouth of the well. Then we will water the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still talking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she was a shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw Rachel daughter of his uncle Laban, and Laban’s sheep, he went over and rolled the stone away from the mouth of the well and watered his uncle’s sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and began to weep aloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had told Rachel that he was a relative of her father and a son of Rebekah. So she ran and told her father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Laban heard the news about Jacob, his sister’s son, he hurried to meet him. He embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his home, and there Jacob told him all these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Laban said to him, “You are my own flesh and blood.”
After Jacob had stayed with him for a whole month,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said to him, “Just because you are a relative of mine, should you work for me for nothing? Tell me what your wages should be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Laban had two daughters; the name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah had weak eyes, but Rachel had a lovely figure and was beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob was in love with Rachel and said, “I’ll work for you seven years in return for your younger daughter Rachel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “It’s better that I give her to you than to some other man. Stay here with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob served seven years to get Rachel, but they seemed like only a few days to him because of his love for her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife. My time is completed, and I want to make love to her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban brought together all the people of the place and gave a feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when evening came, he took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob made love to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Laban gave his servant Zilpah to his daughter as her attendant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When morning came, there was Leah! So Jacob said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? I served you for Rachel, didn’t I? Why have you deceived me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban replied, “It is not our custom here to give the younger daughter in marriage before the older one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finish this daughter’s bridal week; then we will give you the younger one also, in return for another seven years of work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jacob did so. He finished the week with Leah, and then Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban gave his servant Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her attendant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob made love to Rachel also, and his love for Rachel was greater than his love for Leah. And he worked for Laban another seven years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord saw that Leah was not loved, he enabled her to conceive, but Rachel remained childless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, for she said, “It is because the Lord has seen my misery. Surely my husband will love me now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “Because the Lord heard that I am not loved, he gave me this one too.” So she named him Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again she conceived, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “Now at last my husband will become attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.” So he was named Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “This time I will praise the Lord.” So she named him Judah. Then she stopped having children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rachel saw that she was not bearing Jacob any children, she became jealous of her sister. So she said to Jacob, “Give me children, or I’ll die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob became angry with her and said, “Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “Here is Bilhah, my servant. Sleep with her so that she can bear children for me and I too can build a family through her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife. Jacob slept with her,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and she became pregnant and bore him a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel said, “God has vindicated me; he has listened to my plea and given me a son.” Because of this she named him Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel’s servant Bilhah conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel said, “I have had a great struggle with my sister, and I have won.” So she named him Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took her servant Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah’s servant Zilpah bore Jacob a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “What good fortune!” So she named him Gad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah’s servant Zilpah bore Jacob a second son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “How happy I am! The women will call me happy.” So she named him Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During wheat harvest, Reuben went out into the fields and found some mandrake plants, which he brought to his mother Leah. Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But she said to her, “Wasn’t it enough that you took away my husband? Will you take my son’s mandrakes too?”
“Very well,” Rachel said, “he can sleep with you tonight in return for your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when Jacob came in from the fields that evening, Leah went out to meet him. “You must sleep with me,” she said. “I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.” So he slept with her that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God listened to Leah, and she became pregnant and bore Jacob a fifth son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “God has rewarded me for giving my servant to my husband.” So she named him Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah conceived again and bore Jacob a sixth son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “God has presented me with a precious gift. This time my husband will treat me with honor, because I have borne him six sons.” So she named him Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God remembered Rachel; he listened to her and enabled her to conceive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant and gave birth to a son and said, “God has taken away my disgrace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She named him Joseph, and said, “May the Lord add to me another son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Rachel gave birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me on my way so I can go back to my own homeland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me my wives and children, for whom I have served you, and I will be on my way. You know how much work I’ve done for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Laban said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He added, “Name your wages, and I will pay them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to him, “You know how I have worked for you and how your livestock has fared under my care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The little you had before I came has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I have been. But now, when may I do something for my own household?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What shall I give you?” he asked.
“Don’t give me anything,” Jacob replied. “But if you will do this one thing for me, I will go on tending your flocks and watching over them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let me go through all your flocks today and remove from them every speckled or spotted sheep, every dark-colored lamb and every spotted or speckled goat. They will be my wages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And my honesty will testify for me in the future, whenever you check on the wages you have paid me. Any goat in my possession that is not speckled or spotted, or any lamb that is not dark-colored, will be considered stolen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Agreed,” said Laban. “Let it be as you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day he removed all the male goats that were streaked or spotted, and all the speckled or spotted female goats (all that had white on them) and all the dark-colored lambs, and he placed them in the care of his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he put a three-day journey between himself and Jacob, while Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban’s flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob, however, took fresh-cut branches from poplar, almond and plane trees and made white stripes on them by peeling the bark and exposing the white inner wood of the branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he placed the peeled branches in all the watering troughs, so that they would be directly in front of the flocks when they came to drink. When the flocks were in heat and came to drink,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they mated in front of the branches. And they bore young that were streaked or speckled or spotted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set apart the young of the flock by themselves, but made the rest face the streaked and dark-colored animals that belonged to Laban. Thus he made separate flocks for himself and did not put them with Laban’s animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the stronger females were in heat, Jacob would place the branches in the troughs in front of the animals so they would mate near the branches,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but if the animals were weak, he would not place them there. So the weak animals went to Laban and the strong ones to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way the man grew exceedingly prosperous and came to own large flocks, and female and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob heard that Laban’s sons were saying, “Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jacob noticed that Laban’s attitude toward him was not what it had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “I see that your father’s attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that I’ve worked for your father with all my strength,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he said, ‘The speckled ones will be your wages,’ then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, ‘The streaked ones will be your wages,’ then all the flocks bore streaked young.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God has taken away your father’s livestock and has given them to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of God said to me in the dream, ‘Jacob.’ I answered, ‘Here I am.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said, ‘Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel and Leah replied, “Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father’s estate?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Does he not regard us as foreigners? Not only has he sold us, but he has used up what was paid for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Surely all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob put his children and his wives on camels,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he drove all his livestock ahead of him, along with all the goods he had accumulated in Paddan Aram, to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father’s household gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him he was running away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he fled with all he had, crossed the Euphrates River, and headed for the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Taking his relatives with him, he pursued Jacob for seven days and caught up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and said to him, “Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country of Gilead when Laban overtook him, and Laban and his relatives camped there too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? You’ve deceived me, and you’ve carried off my daughters like captives in war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you run off secretly and deceive me? Why didn’t you tell me, so I could send you away with joy and singing to the music of timbrels and harps?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You didn’t even let me kiss my grandchildren and my daughters goodbye. You have done a foolish thing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have the power to harm you; but last night the God of your father said to me, ‘Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you have gone off because you longed to return to your father’s household. But why did you steal my gods?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob answered Laban, “I was afraid, because I thought you would take your daughters away from me by force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you find anyone who has your gods, that person shall not live. In the presence of our relatives, see for yourself whether there is anything of yours here with me; and if so, take it.” Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban went into Jacob’s tent and into Leah’s tent and into the tent of the two female servants, but he found nothing. After he came out of Leah’s tent, he entered Rachel’s tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rachel had taken the household gods and put them inside her camel’s saddle and was sitting on them. Laban searched through everything in the tent but found nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel said to her father, “Don’t be angry, my lord, that I cannot stand up in your presence; I’m having my period.” So he searched but could not find the household gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob was angry and took Laban to task. “What is my crime?” he asked Laban. “How have I wronged you that you hunt me down?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now that you have searched through all my goods, what have you found that belongs to your household? Put it here in front of your relatives and mine, and let them judge between the two of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have been with you for twenty years now. Your sheep and goats have not miscarried, nor have I eaten rams from your flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I did not bring you animals torn by wild beasts; I bore the loss myself. And you demanded payment from me for whatever was stolen by day or night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was my situation: The heat consumed me in the daytime and the cold at night, and sleep fled from my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was like this for the twenty years I was in your household. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flocks, and you changed my wages ten times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been with me, you would surely have sent me away empty-handed. But God has seen my hardship and the toil of my hands, and last night he rebuked you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban answered Jacob, “The women are my daughters, the children are my children, and the flocks are my flocks. All you see is mine. Yet what can I do today about these daughters of mine, or about the children they have borne?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come now, let’s make a covenant, you and I, and let it serve as a witness between us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his relatives, “Gather some stones.” So they took stones and piled them in a heap, and they ate there by the heap.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha, and Jacob called it Galeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “This heap is a witness between you and me today.” That is why it was called Galeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was also called Mizpah, because he said, “May the Lord keep watch between you and me when we are away from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you mistreat my daughters or if you take any wives besides my daughters, even though no one is with us, remember that God is a witness between you and me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban also said to Jacob, “Here is this heap, and here is this pillar I have set up between you and me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This heap is a witness, and this pillar is a witness, that I will not go past this heap to your side to harm you and that you will not go past this heap and pillar to my side to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.”
So Jacob took an oath in the name of the Fear of his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered a sacrifice there in the hill country and invited his relatives to a meal. After they had eaten, they spent the night there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them. Then he left and returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob also went on his way, and the angels of God met him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw them, he said, “This is the camp of God!” So he named that place Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed them: “This is what you are to say to my lord Esau: ‘Your servant Jacob says, I have been staying with Laban and have remained there till now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have cattle and donkeys, sheep and goats, male and female servants. Now I am sending this message to my lord, that I may find favor in your eyes.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messengers returned to Jacob, they said, “We went to your brother Esau, and now he is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In great fear and distress Jacob divided the people who were with him into two groups, and the flocks and herds and camels as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He thought, “If Esau comes and attacks one group, the group that is left may escape.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob prayed, “O God of my father Abraham, God of my father Isaac, Lord, you who said to me, ‘Go back to your country and your relatives, and I will make you prosper,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am unworthy of all the kindness and faithfulness you have shown your servant. I had only my staff when I crossed this Jordan, but now I have become two camps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Save me, I pray, from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am afraid he will come and attack me, and also the mothers with their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you have said, ‘I will surely make you prosper and will make your descendants like the sand of the sea, which cannot be counted.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spent the night there, and from what he had with him he selected a gift for his brother Esau:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: thirty female camels with their young, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put them in the care of his servants, each herd by itself, and said to his servants, “Go ahead of me, and keep some space between the herds.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed the one in the lead: “When my brother Esau meets you and asks, ‘Who do you belong to, and where are you going, and who owns all these animals in front of you?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you are to say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and he is coming behind us.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also instructed the second, the third and all the others who followed the herds: “You are to say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And be sure to say, ‘Your servant Jacob is coming behind us.’” For he thought, “I will pacify him with these gifts I am sending on ahead; later, when I see him, perhaps he will receive me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob’s gifts went on ahead of him, but he himself spent the night in the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two female servants and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had sent them across the stream, he sent over all his possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him till daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the man saw that he could not overpower him, he touched the socket of Jacob’s hip so that his hip was wrenched as he wrestled with the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the man said, “Let me go, for it is daybreak.”
But Jacob replied, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man asked him, “What is your name?”
“Jacob,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with humans and have overcome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob said, “Please tell me your name.”
But he replied, “Why do you ask my name?” Then he blessed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob called the place Peniel, saying, “It is because I saw God face to face, and yet my life was spared.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun rose above him as he passed Peniel, and he was limping because of his hip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the socket of Jacob’s hip was touched near the tendon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob looked up and there was Esau, coming with his four hundred men; so he divided the children among Leah, Rachel and the two female servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the female servants and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph in the rear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He himself went on ahead and bowed down to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Esau ran to meet Jacob and embraced him; he threw his arms around his neck and kissed him. And they wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Esau looked up and saw the women and children. “Who are these with you?” he asked.
Jacob answered, “They are the children God has graciously given your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the female servants and their children approached and bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next, Leah and her children came and bowed down. Last of all came Joseph and Rachel, and they too bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Esau asked, “What’s the meaning of all these flocks and herds I met?”
“To find favor in your eyes, my lord,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Esau said, “I already have plenty, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, please!” said Jacob. “If I have found favor in your eyes, accept this gift from me. For to see your face is like seeing the face of God, now that you have received me favorably.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please accept the present that was brought to you, for God has been gracious to me and I have all I need.” And because Jacob insisted, Esau accepted it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Esau said, “Let us be on our way; I’ll accompany you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are tender and that I must care for the ewes and cows that are nursing their young. If they are driven hard just one day, all the animals will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So let my lord go on ahead of his servant, while I move along slowly at the pace of the flocks and herds before me and the pace of the children, until I come to my lord in Seir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Esau said, “Then let me leave some of my men with you.”
“But why do that?” Jacob asked. “Just let me find favor in the eyes of my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that day Esau started on his way back to Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob, however, went to Sukkoth, where he built a place for himself and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place is called Sukkoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Jacob came from Paddan Aram, he arrived safely at the city of Shechem in Canaan and camped within sight of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a hundred pieces of silver, he bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, the plot of ground where he pitched his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he set up an altar and called it El Elohe Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Dinah, the daughter Leah had borne to Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the ruler of that area, saw her, he took her and raped her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His heart was drawn to Dinah daughter of Jacob; he loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Shechem said to his father Hamor, “Get me this girl as my wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob heard that his daughter Dinah had been defiled, his sons were in the fields with his livestock; so he did nothing about it until they came home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shechem’s father Hamor went out to talk with Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Jacob’s sons had come in from the fields as soon as they heard what had happened. They were shocked and furious, because Shechem had done an outrageous thing in Israel by sleeping with Jacob’s daughter—a thing that should not be done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hamor said to them, “My son Shechem has his heart set on your daughter. Please give her to him as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Intermarry with us; give us your daughters and take our daughters for yourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can settle among us; the land is open to you. Live in it, trade in it, and acquire property in it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shechem said to Dinah’s father and brothers, “Let me find favor in your eyes, and I will give you whatever you ask.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the price for the bride and the gift I am to bring as great as you like, and I’ll pay whatever you ask me. Only give me the young woman as my wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because their sister Dinah had been defiled, Jacob’s sons replied deceitfully as they spoke to Shechem and his father Hamor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to them, “We can’t do such a thing; we can’t give our sister to a man who is not circumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will enter into an agreement with you on one condition only: that you become like us by circumcising all your males.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we will give you our daughters and take your daughters for ourselves. We’ll settle among you and become one people with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you will not agree to be circumcised, we’ll take our sister and go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their proposal seemed good to Hamor and his son Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man, who was the most honored of all his father’s family, lost no time in doing what they said, because he was delighted with Jacob’s daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hamor and his son Shechem went to the gate of their city to speak to the men of their city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These men are friendly toward us,” they said. “Let them live in our land and trade in it; the land has plenty of room for them. We can marry their daughters and they can marry ours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men will agree to live with us as one people only on the condition that our males be circumcised, as they themselves are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Won’t their livestock, their property and all their other animals become ours? So let us agree to their terms, and they will settle among us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men who went out of the city gate agreed with Hamor and his son Shechem, and every male in the city was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later, while all of them were still in pain, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took their swords and attacked the unsuspecting city, killing every male.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put Hamor and his son Shechem to the sword and took Dinah from Shechem’s house and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Jacob came upon the dead bodies and looted the city where their sister had been defiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They seized their flocks and herds and donkeys and everything else of theirs in the city and out in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried off all their wealth and all their women and children, taking as plunder everything in the houses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble on me by making me obnoxious to the Canaanites and Perizzites, the people living in this land. We are few in number, and if they join forces against me and attack me, I and my household will be destroyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they replied, “Should he have treated our sister like a prostitute?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said to Jacob, “Go up to Bethel and settle there, and build an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Get rid of the foreign gods you have with you, and purify yourselves and change your clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then come, let us go up to Bethel, where I will build an altar to God, who answered me in the day of my distress and who has been with me wherever I have gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
