verses.text: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods they had and the rings in their ears, and Jacob buried them under the oak at Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they set out, and the terror of God fell on the towns all around them so that no one pursued them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob and all the people with him came to Luz (that is, Bethel) in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he built an altar, and he called the place El Bethel, because it was there that God revealed himself to him when he was fleeing from his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried under the oak outside Bethel. So it was named Allon Bakuth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Jacob returned from Paddan Aram, God appeared to him again and blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob, but you will no longer be called Jacob; your name will be Israel.” So he named him Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And God said to him, “I am God Almighty; be fruitful and increase in number. A nation and a community of nations will come from you, and kings will be among your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land I gave to Abraham and Isaac I also give to you, and I will give this land to your descendants after you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God went up from him at the place where he had talked with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set up a stone pillar at the place where God had talked with him, and he poured out a drink offering on it; he also poured oil on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob called the place where God had talked with him Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they moved on from Bethel. While they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth and had great difficulty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as she was having great difficulty in childbirth, the midwife said to her, “Don’t despair, for you have another son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she breathed her last—for she was dying—she named her son Ben-Oni. But his father named him Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Over her tomb Jacob set up a pillar, and to this day that pillar marks Rachel’s tomb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel moved on again and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While Israel was living in that region, Reuben went in and slept with his father’s concubine Bilhah, and Israel heard of it.
Jacob had twelve sons:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Leah:
Reuben the firstborn of Jacob,
Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar and Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Rachel:
Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Rachel’s servant Bilhah:
Dan and Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Leah’s servant Zilpah:
Gad and Asher.
These were the sons of Jacob, who were born to him in Paddan Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob came home to his father Isaac in Mamre, near Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had stayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac lived a hundred and eighty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he breathed his last and died and was gathered to his people, old and full of years. And his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the family line of Esau (that is, Edom).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took his wives from the women of Canaan: Adah daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: also Basemath daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, Basemath bore Reuel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These were the sons of Esau, who were born to him in Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took his wives and sons and daughters and all the members of his household, as well as his livestock and all his other animals and all the goods he had acquired in Canaan, and moved to a land some distance from his brother Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their possessions were too great for them to remain together; the land where they were staying could not support them both because of their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau (that is, Edom) settled in the hill country of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the family line of Esau the father of the Edomites in the hill country of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the names of Esau’s sons:
Eliphaz, the son of Esau’s wife Adah, and Reuel, the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Eliphaz:
Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam and Kenaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau’s son Eliphaz also had a concubine named Timna, who bore him Amalek. These were grandsons of Esau’s wife Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Reuel:
Nahath, Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These were grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon, whom she bore to Esau:
Jeush, Jalam and Korah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the chiefs among Esau’s descendants:
The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau:
Chiefs Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Korah, Gatam and Amalek. These were the chiefs descended from Eliphaz in Edom; they were grandsons of Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Esau’s son Reuel:
Chiefs Nahath, Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These were the chiefs descended from Reuel in Edom; they were grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah:
Chiefs Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These were the chiefs descended from Esau’s wife Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Esau (that is, Edom), and these were their chiefs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the sons of Seir the Horite, who were living in the region:
Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer and Dishan. These sons of Seir in Edom were Horite chiefs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Lotan:
Hori and Homam. Timna was Lotan’s sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Shobal:
Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho and Onam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Zibeon:
Aiah and Anah. This is the Anah who discovered the hot springs in the desert while he was grazing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The children of Anah:
Dishon and Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Dishon:
Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran and Keran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Ezer:
Bilhan, Zaavan and Akan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Dishan:
Uz and Aran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the Horite chiefs:
Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer and Dishan. These were the Horite chiefs, according to their divisions, in the land of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the kings who reigned in Edom before any Israelite king reigned:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bela son of Beor became king of Edom. His city was named Dinhabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, succeeded him as king. His city was named Avith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the river succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Akbor succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baal-Hanan son of Akbor died, Hadad succeeded him as king. His city was named Pau, and his wife’s name was Mehetabel daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-Zahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the chiefs descended from Esau, by name, according to their clans and regions:
Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Magdiel and Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they occupied.
This is the family line of Esau, the father of the Edomites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob lived in the land where his father had stayed, the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Jacob’s family line.
Joseph, a young man of seventeen, was tending the flocks with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, his father’s wives, and he brought their father a bad report about them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than any of his other sons, because he had been born to him in his old age; and he made an ornate robe for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his brothers saw that their father loved him more than any of them, they hated him and could not speak a kind word to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph had a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him all the more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Listen to this dream I had:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were binding sheaves of grain out in the field when suddenly my sheaf rose and stood upright, while your sheaves gathered around mine and bowed down to it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers said to him, “Do you intend to reign over us? Will you actually rule us?” And they hated him all the more because of his dream and what he had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he had another dream, and he told it to his brothers. “Listen,” he said, “I had another dream, and this time the sun and moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he told his father as well as his brothers, his father rebuked him and said, “What is this dream you had? Will your mother and I and your brothers actually come and bow down to the ground before you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now his brothers had gone to graze their father’s flocks near Shechem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and Israel said to Joseph, “As you know, your brothers are grazing the flocks near Shechem. Come, I am going to send you to them.”
“Very well,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he said to him, “Go and see if all is well with your brothers and with the flocks, and bring word back to me.” Then he sent him off from the Valley of Hebron.
When Joseph arrived at Shechem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a man found him wandering around in the fields and asked him, “What are you looking for?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “I’m looking for my brothers. Can you tell me where they are grazing their flocks?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They have moved on from here,” the man answered. “I heard them say, ‘Let’s go to Dothan.’”
So Joseph went after his brothers and found them near Dothan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they saw him in the distance, and before he reached them, they plotted to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here comes that dreamer!” they said to each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come now, let’s kill him and throw him into one of these cisterns and say that a ferocious animal devoured him. Then we’ll see what comes of his dreams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Reuben heard this, he tried to rescue him from their hands. “Let’s not take his life,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t shed any blood. Throw him into this cistern here in the wilderness, but don’t lay a hand on him.” Reuben said this to rescue him from them and take him back to his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his robe—the ornate robe he was wearing—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they took him and threw him into the cistern. The cistern was empty; there was no water in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they sat down to eat their meal, they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were loaded with spices, balm and myrrh, and they were on their way to take them down to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said to his brothers, “What will we gain if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let’s sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands on him; after all, he is our brother, our own flesh and blood.” His brothers agreed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the Midianite merchants came by, his brothers pulled Joseph up out of the cistern and sold him for twenty shekels of silver to the Ishmaelites, who took him to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Reuben returned to the cistern and saw that Joseph was not there, he tore his clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went back to his brothers and said, “The boy isn’t there! Where can I turn now?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they got Joseph’s robe, slaughtered a goat and dipped the robe in the blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the ornate robe back to their father and said, “We found this. Examine it to see whether it is your son’s robe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He recognized it and said, “It is my son’s robe! Some ferocious animal has devoured him. Joseph has surely been torn to pieces.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and mourned for his son many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his sons and daughters came to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. “No,” he said, “I will continue to mourn until I join my son in the grave.” So his father wept for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s officials, the captain of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, Judah left his brothers and went down to stay with a man of Adullam named Hirah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Judah met the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua. He married her and made love to her;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she became pregnant and gave birth to a son, who was named Er.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son and named him Onan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave birth to still another son and named him Shelah. It was at Kezib that she gave birth to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah got a wife for Er, his firstborn, and her name was Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the Lord’s sight; so the Lord put him to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Sleep with your brother’s wife and fulfill your duty to her as a brother-in-law to raise up offspring for your brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Onan knew that the child would not be his; so whenever he slept with his brother’s wife, he spilled his semen on the ground to keep from providing offspring for his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What he did was wicked in the Lord’s sight; so the Lord put him to death also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah then said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Live as a widow in your father’s household until my son Shelah grows up.” For he thought, “He may die too, just like his brothers.” So Tamar went to live in her father’s household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a long time Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died. When Judah had recovered from his grief, he went up to Timnah, to the men who were shearing his sheep, and his friend Hirah the Adullamite went with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Tamar was told, “Your father-in-law is on his way to Timnah to shear his sheep,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she took off her widow’s clothes, covered herself with a veil to disguise herself, and then sat down at the entrance to Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah. For she saw that, though Shelah had now grown up, she had not been given to him as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, for she had covered her face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Not realizing that she was his daughter-in-law, he went over to her by the roadside and said, “Come now, let me sleep with you.”
“And what will you give me to sleep with you?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ll send you a young goat from my flock,” he said.
“Will you give me something as a pledge until you send it?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “What pledge should I give you?”
“Your seal and its cord, and the staff in your hand,” she answered. So he gave them to her and slept with her, and she became pregnant by him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After she left, she took off her veil and put on her widow’s clothes again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile Judah sent the young goat by his friend the Adullamite in order to get his pledge back from the woman, but he did not find her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He asked the men who lived there, “Where is the shrine prostitute who was beside the road at Enaim?”
“There hasn’t been any shrine prostitute here,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he went back to Judah and said, “I didn’t find her. Besides, the men who lived there said, ‘There hasn’t been any shrine prostitute here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said, “Let her keep what she has, or we will become a laughingstock. After all, I did send her this young goat, but you didn’t find her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
About three months later Judah was told, “Your daughter-in-law Tamar is guilty of prostitution, and as a result she is now pregnant.”
Judah said, “Bring her out and have her burned to death!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was being brought out, she sent a message to her father-in-law. “I am pregnant by the man who owns these,” she said. And she added, “See if you recognize whose seal and cord and staff these are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah recognized them and said, “She is more righteous than I, since I wouldn’t give her to my son Shelah.” And he did not sleep with her again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time came for her to give birth, there were twin boys in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was giving birth, one of them put out his hand; so the midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his wrist and said, “This one came out first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he drew back his hand, his brother came out, and she said, “So this is how you have broken out!” And he was named Perez.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his brother, who had the scarlet thread on his wrist, came out. And he was named Zerah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh’s officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph’s care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate.
Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and after a while his master’s wife took notice of Joseph and said, “Come to bed with me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused. “With me in charge,” he told her, “my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She caught him by his cloak and said, “Come to bed with me!” But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she called her household servants. “Look,” she said to them, “this Hebrew has been brought to us to make sport of us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard me scream for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she told him this story: “That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to make sport of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, “This is how your slave treated me,” he burned with anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph’s master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king’s prisoners were confined.
But while Joseph was there in the prison,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph’s care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt offended their master, the king of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was angry with his two officials, the chief cupbearer and the chief baker,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and put them in custody in the house of the captain of the guard, in the same prison where Joseph was confined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The captain of the guard assigned them to Joseph, and he attended them.
After they had been in custody for some time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: each of the two men—the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were being held in prison—had a dream the same night, and each dream had a meaning of its own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph came to them the next morning, he saw that they were dejected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he asked Pharaoh’s officials who were in custody with him in his master’s house, “Why do you look so sad today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“We both had dreams,” they answered, “but there is no one to interpret them.”
Then Joseph said to them, “Do not interpretations belong to God? Tell me your dreams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. He said to him, “In my dream I saw a vine in front of me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and on the vine were three branches. As soon as it budded, it blossomed, and its clusters ripened into grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes, squeezed them into Pharaoh’s cup and put the cup in his hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what it means,” Joseph said to him. “The three branches are three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your position, and you will put Pharaoh’s cup in his hand, just as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when all goes well with you, remember me and show me kindness; mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was forcibly carried off from the land of the Hebrews, and even here I have done nothing to deserve being put in a dungeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chief baker saw that Joseph had given a favorable interpretation, he said to Joseph, “I too had a dream: On my head were three baskets of bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the top basket were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what it means,” Joseph said. “The three baskets are three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift off your head and impale your body on a pole. And the birds will eat away your flesh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the third day was Pharaoh’s birthday, and he gave a feast for all his officials. He lifted up the heads of the chief cupbearer and the chief baker in the presence of his officials:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He restored the chief cupbearer to his position, so that he once again put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but he impaled the chief baker, just as Joseph had said to them in his interpretation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief cupbearer, however, did not remember Joseph; he forgot him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When two full years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream: He was standing by the Nile,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when out of the river there came up seven cows, sleek and fat, and they grazed among the reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After them, seven other cows, ugly and gaunt, came up out of the Nile and stood beside those on the riverbank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the cows that were ugly and gaunt ate up the seven sleek, fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He fell asleep again and had a second dream: Seven heads of grain, healthy and good, were growing on a single stalk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After them, seven other heads of grain sprouted—thin and scorched by the east wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven healthy, full heads. Then Pharaoh woke up; it had been a dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning his mind was troubled, so he sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, “Today I am reminded of my shortcomings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was once angry with his servants, and he imprisoned me and the chief baker in the house of the captain of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of us had a dream the same night, and each dream had a meaning of its own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a young Hebrew was there with us, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted them for us, giving each man the interpretation of his dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And things turned out exactly as he interpreted them to us: I was restored to my position, and the other man was impaled.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and he was quickly brought from the dungeon. When he had shaved and changed his clothes, he came before Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I had a dream, and no one can interpret it. But I have heard it said of you that when you hear a dream you can interpret it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I cannot do it,” Joseph replied to Pharaoh, “but God will give Pharaoh the answer he desires.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when out of the river there came up seven cows, fat and sleek, and they grazed among the reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After them, seven other cows came up—scrawny and very ugly and lean. I had never seen such ugly cows in all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lean, ugly cows ate up the seven fat cows that came up first.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But even after they ate them, no one could tell that they had done so; they looked just as ugly as before. Then I woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In my dream I saw seven heads of grain, full and good, growing on a single stalk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After them, seven other heads sprouted—withered and thin and scorched by the east wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven good heads. I told this to the magicians, but none of them could explain it to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, “The dreams of Pharaoh are one and the same. God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads of grain are seven years; it is one and the same dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven lean, ugly cows that came up afterward are seven years, and so are the seven worthless heads of grain scorched by the east wind: They are seven years of famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It is just as I said to Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but seven years of famine will follow them. Then all the abundance in Egypt will be forgotten, and the famine will ravage the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The abundance in the land will not be remembered, because the famine that follows it will be so severe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The reason the dream was given to Pharaoh in two forms is that the matter has been firmly decided by God, and God will do it soon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now let Pharaoh look for a discerning and wise man and put him in charge of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let Pharaoh appoint commissioners over the land to take a fifth of the harvest of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They should collect all the food of these good years that are coming and store up the grain under the authority of Pharaoh, to be kept in the cities for food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This food should be held in reserve for the country, to be used during the seven years of famine that will come upon Egypt, so that the country may not be ruined by the famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The plan seemed good to Pharaoh and to all his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh asked them, “Can we find anyone like this man, one in whom is the spirit of God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall be in charge of my palace, and all my people are to submit to your orders. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I hereby put you in charge of the whole land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his finger and put it on Joseph’s finger. He dressed him in robes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had him ride in a chariot as his second-in-command, and people shouted before him, “Make way!” Thus he put him in charge of the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but without your word no one will lift hand or foot in all Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-Paneah and gave him Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife. And Joseph went throughout the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was thirty years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from Pharaoh’s presence and traveled throughout Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the seven years of abundance the land produced plentifully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph collected all the food produced in those seven years of abundance in Egypt and stored it in the cities. In each city he put the food grown in the fields surrounding it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph stored up huge quantities of grain, like the sand of the sea; it was so much that he stopped keeping records because it was beyond measure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before the years of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh and said, “It is because God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father’s household.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The second son he named Ephraim and said, “It is because God has made me fruitful in the land of my suffering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven years of abundance in Egypt came to an end,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in all the other lands, but in the whole land of Egypt there was food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Egypt began to feel the famine, the people cried to Pharaoh for food. Then Pharaoh told all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph and do what he tells you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the famine had spread over the whole country, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe throughout Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the world came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph, because the famine was severe everywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why do you just keep looking at each other?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He continued, “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may live and not die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph’s brother, with the others, because he was afraid that harm might come to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel’s sons were among those who went to buy grain, for there was famine in the land of Canaan also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph was the governor of the land, the person who sold grain to all its people. So when Joseph’s brothers arrived, they bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As soon as Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them, but he pretended to be a stranger and spoke harshly to them. “Where do you come from?” he asked.
“From the land of Canaan,” they replied, “to buy food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not recognize him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he remembered his dreams about them and said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, my lord,” they answered. “Your servants have come to buy food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are all the sons of one man. Your servants are honest men, not spies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No!” he said to them. “You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they replied, “Your servants were twelve brothers, the sons of one man, who lives in the land of Canaan. The youngest is now with our father, and one is no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “It is just as I told you: You are spies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is how you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Send one of your number to get your brother; the rest of you will be kept in prison, so that your words may be tested to see if you are telling the truth. If you are not, then as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he put them all in custody for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, Joseph said to them, “Do this and you will live, for I fear God:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you are honest men, let one of your brothers stay here in prison, while the rest of you go and take grain back for your starving households.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must bring your youngest brother to me, so that your words may be verified and that you may not die.” This they proceeded to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to one another, “Surely we are being punished because of our brother. We saw how distressed he was when he pleaded with us for his life, but we would not listen; that’s why this distress has come on us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben replied, “Didn’t I tell you not to sin against the boy? But you wouldn’t listen! Now we must give an accounting for his blood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did not realize that Joseph could understand them, since he was using an interpreter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He turned away from them and began to weep, but then came back and spoke to them again. He had Simeon taken from them and bound before their eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph gave orders to fill their bags with grain, to put each man’s silver back in his sack, and to give them provisions for their journey. After this was done for them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the place where they stopped for the night one of them opened his sack to get feed for his donkey, and he saw his silver in the mouth of his sack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My silver has been returned,” he said to his brothers. “Here it is in my sack.”
Their hearts sank and they turned to each other trembling and said, “What is this that God has done to us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him all that had happened to them. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The man who is lord over the land spoke harshly to us and treated us as though we were spying on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we said to him, ‘We are honest men; we are not spies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were twelve brothers, sons of one father. One is no more, and the youngest is now with our father in Canaan.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the man who is lord over the land said to us, ‘This is how I will know whether you are honest men: Leave one of your brothers here with me, and take food for your starving households and go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But bring your youngest brother to me so I will know that you are not spies but honest men. Then I will give your brother back to you, and you can trade in the land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were emptying their sacks, there in each man’s sack was his pouch of silver! When they and their father saw the money pouches, they were frightened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father Jacob said to them, “You have deprived me of my children. Joseph is no more and Simeon is no more, and now you want to take Benjamin. Everything is against me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Reuben said to his father, “You may put both of my sons to death if I do not bring him back to you. Entrust him to my care, and I will bring him back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob said, “My son will not go down there with you; his brother is dead and he is the only one left. If harm comes to him on the journey you are taking, you will bring my gray head down to the grave in sorrow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the famine was still severe in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when they had eaten all the grain they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them, “Go back and buy us a little more food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Judah said to him, “The man warned us solemnly, ‘You will not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you will send our brother along with us, we will go down and buy food for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you will not send him, we will not go down, because the man said to us, ‘You will not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel asked, “Why did you bring this trouble on me by telling the man you had another brother?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “The man questioned us closely about ourselves and our family. ‘Is your father still living?’ he asked us. ‘Do you have another brother?’ We simply answered his questions. How were we to know he would say, ‘Bring your brother down here’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to Israel his father, “Send the boy along with me and we will go at once, so that we and you and our children may live and not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will guarantee his safety; you can hold me personally responsible for him. If I do not bring him back to you and set him here before you, I will bear the blame before you all my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As it is, if we had not delayed, we could have gone and returned twice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then their father Israel said to them, “If it must be, then do this: Put some of the best products of the land in your bags and take them down to the man as a gift—a little balm and a little honey, some spices and myrrh, some pistachio nuts and almonds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take double the amount of silver with you, for you must return the silver that was put back into the mouths of your sacks. Perhaps it was a mistake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take your brother also and go back to the man at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may God Almighty grant you mercy before the man so that he will let your other brother and Benjamin come back with you. As for me, if I am bereaved, I am bereaved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men took the gifts and double the amount of silver, and Benjamin also. They hurried down to Egypt and presented themselves to Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the steward of his house, “Take these men to my house, slaughter an animal and prepare a meal; they are to eat with me at noon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man did as Joseph told him and took the men to Joseph’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the men were frightened when they were taken to his house. They thought, “We were brought here because of the silver that was put back into our sacks the first time. He wants to attack us and overpower us and seize us as slaves and take our donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went up to Joseph’s steward and spoke to him at the entrance to the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We beg your pardon, our lord,” they said, “we came down here the first time to buy food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But at the place where we stopped for the night we opened our sacks and each of us found his silver—the exact weight—in the mouth of his sack. So we have brought it back with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have also brought additional silver with us to buy food. We don’t know who put our silver in our sacks.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It’s all right,” he said. “Don’t be afraid. Your God, the God of your father, has given you treasure in your sacks; I received your silver.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The steward took the men into Joseph’s house, gave them water to wash their feet and provided fodder for their donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They prepared their gifts for Joseph’s arrival at noon, because they had heard that they were to eat there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph came home, they presented to him the gifts they had brought into the house, and they bowed down before him to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them how they were, and then he said, “How is your aged father you told me about? Is he still living?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “Your servant our father is still alive and well.” And they bowed down, prostrating themselves before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he looked about and saw his brother Benjamin, his own mother’s son, he asked, “Is this your youngest brother, the one you told me about?” And he said, “God be gracious to you, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deeply moved at the sight of his brother, Joseph hurried out and looked for a place to weep. He went into his private room and wept there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had washed his face, he came out and, controlling himself, said, “Serve the food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They served him by himself, the brothers by themselves, and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves, because Egyptians could not eat with Hebrews, for that is detestable to Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men had been seated before him in the order of their ages, from the firstborn to the youngest; and they looked at each other in astonishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When portions were served to them from Joseph’s table, Benjamin’s portion was five times as much as anyone else’s. So they feasted and drank freely with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph gave these instructions to the steward of his house: “Fill the men’s sacks with as much food as they can carry, and put each man’s silver in the mouth of his sack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then put my cup, the silver one, in the mouth of the youngest one’s sack, along with the silver for his grain.” And he did as Joseph said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As morning dawned, the men were sent on their way with their donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had not gone far from the city when Joseph said to his steward, “Go after those men at once, and when you catch up with them, say to them, ‘Why have you repaid good with evil?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t this the cup my master drinks from and also uses for divination? This is a wicked thing you have done.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he caught up with them, he repeated these words to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they said to him, “Why does my lord say such things? Far be it from your servants to do anything like that!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We even brought back to you from the land of Canaan the silver we found inside the mouths of our sacks. So why would we steal silver or gold from your master’s house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of your servants is found to have it, he will die; and the rest of us will become my lord’s slaves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Very well, then,” he said, “let it be as you say. Whoever is found to have it will become my slave; the rest of you will be free from blame.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of them quickly lowered his sack to the ground and opened it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the steward proceeded to search, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest. And the cup was found in Benjamin’s sack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this, they tore their clothes. Then they all loaded their donkeys and returned to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was still in the house when Judah and his brothers came in, and they threw themselves to the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “What is this you have done? Don’t you know that a man like me can find things out by divination?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What can we say to my lord?” Judah replied. “What can we say? How can we prove our innocence? God has uncovered your servants’ guilt. We are now my lord’s slaves—we ourselves and the one who was found to have the cup.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joseph said, “Far be it from me to do such a thing! Only the man who was found to have the cup will become my slave. The rest of you, go back to your father in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah went up to him and said: “Pardon your servant, my lord, let me speak a word to my lord. Do not be angry with your servant, though you are equal to Pharaoh himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My lord asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we answered, ‘We have an aged father, and there is a young son born to him in his old age. His brother is dead, and he is the only one of his mother’s sons left, and his father loves him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then you said to your servants, ‘Bring him down to me so I can see him for myself.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father; if he leaves him, his father will die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you told your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we went back to your servant my father, we told him what my lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then our father said, ‘Go back and buy a little more food.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we said, ‘We cannot go down. Only if our youngest brother is with us will we go. We cannot see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your servant my father said to us, ‘You know that my wife bore me two sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of them went away from me, and I said, “He has surely been torn to pieces.” And I have not seen him since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take this one from me too and harm comes to him, you will bring my gray head down to the grave in misery.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now, if the boy is not with us when I go back to your servant my father, and if my father, whose life is closely bound up with the boy’s life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: sees that the boy isn’t there, he will die. Your servants will bring the gray head of our father down to the grave in sorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant guaranteed the boy’s safety to my father. I said, ‘If I do not bring him back to you, I will bear the blame before you, my father, all my life!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now then, please let your servant remain here as my lord’s slave in place of the boy, and let the boy return with his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How can I go back to my father if the boy is not with me? No! Do not let me see the misery that would come on my father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph could no longer control himself before all his attendants, and he cried out, “Have everyone leave my presence!” So there was no one with Joseph when he made himself known to his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he wept so loudly that the Egyptians heard him, and Pharaoh’s household heard about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still living?” But his brothers were not able to answer him, because they were terrified at his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to his brothers, “Come close to me.” When they had done so, he said, “I am your brother Joseph, the one you sold into Egypt!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, do not be distressed and do not be angry with yourselves for selling me here, because it was to save lives that God sent me ahead of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For two years now there has been famine in the land, and for the next five years there will be no plowing and reaping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God sent me ahead of you to preserve for you a remnant on earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So then, it was not you who sent me here, but God. He made me father to Pharaoh, lord of his entire household and ruler of all Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now hurry back to my father and say to him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me; don’t delay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall live in the region of Goshen and be near me—you, your children and grandchildren, your flocks and herds, and all you have.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will provide for you there, because five years of famine are still to come. Otherwise you and your household and all who belong to you will become destitute.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You can see for yourselves, and so can my brother Benjamin, that it is really I who am speaking to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell my father about all the honor accorded me in Egypt and about everything you have seen. And bring my father down here quickly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he threw his arms around his brother Benjamin and wept, and Benjamin embraced him, weeping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he kissed all his brothers and wept over them. Afterward his brothers talked with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the news reached Pharaoh’s palace that Joseph’s brothers had come, Pharaoh and all his officials were pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘Do this: Load your animals and return to the land of Canaan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and bring your father and your families back to me. I will give you the best of the land of Egypt and you can enjoy the fat of the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are also directed to tell them, ‘Do this: Take some carts from Egypt for your children and your wives, and get your father and come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never mind about your belongings, because the best of all Egypt will be yours.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the sons of Israel did this. Joseph gave them carts, as Pharaoh had commanded, and he also gave them provisions for their journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To each of them he gave new clothing, but to Benjamin he gave three hundred shekels of silver and five sets of clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is what he sent to his father: ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and other provisions for his journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent his brothers away, and as they were leaving he said to them, “Don’t quarrel on the way!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went up out of Egypt and came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Joseph is still alive! In fact, he is ruler of all Egypt.” Jacob was stunned; he did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they told him everything Joseph had said to them, and when he saw the carts Joseph had sent to carry him back, the spirit of their father Jacob revived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Israel said, “I’m convinced! My son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel set out with all that was his, and when he reached Beersheba, he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And God spoke to Israel in a vision at night and said, “Jacob! Jacob!”
“Here I am,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am God, the God of your father,” he said. “Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you into a great nation there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go down to Egypt with you, and I will surely bring you back again. And Joseph’s own hand will close your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob left Beersheba, and Israel’s sons took their father Jacob and their children and their wives in the carts that Pharaoh had sent to transport him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob and all his offspring went to Egypt, taking with them their livestock and the possessions they had acquired in Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob brought with him to Egypt his sons and grandsons and his daughters and granddaughters—all his offspring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the names of the sons of Israel (Jacob and his descendants) who went to Egypt:
Reuben the firstborn of Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Reuben:
Hanok, Pallu, Hezron and Karmi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Simeon:
Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Levi:
Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Judah:
Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez and Zerah (but Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan).
The sons of Perez:
Hezron and Hamul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Issachar:
Tola, Puah, Jashub and Shimron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Zebulun:
Sered, Elon and Jahleel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons Leah bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, besides his daughter Dinah. These sons and daughters of his were thirty-three in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Gad:
Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi and Areli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Asher:
Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi and Beriah.
Their sister was Serah.
The sons of Beriah:
Heber and Malkiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the children born to Jacob by Zilpah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Leah—sixteen in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel:
Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Egypt, Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Benjamin:
Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim and Ard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The son of Dan:
Hushim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Naphtali:
Jahziel, Guni, Jezer and Shillem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons born to Jacob by Bilhah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Rachel—seven in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All those who went to Egypt with Jacob—those who were his direct descendants, not counting his sons’ wives—numbered sixty-six persons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the two sons who had been born to Joseph in Egypt, the members of Jacob’s family, which went to Egypt, were seventy in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to get directions to Goshen. When they arrived in the region of Goshen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph had his chariot made ready and went to Goshen to meet his father Israel. As soon as Joseph appeared before him, he threw his arms around his father and wept for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “Now I am ready to die, since I have seen for myself that you are still alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s household, “I will go up and speak to Pharaoh and will say to him, ‘My brothers and my father’s household, who were living in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men are shepherds; they tend livestock, and they have brought along their flocks and herds and everything they own.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh calls you in and asks, ‘What is your occupation?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you should answer, ‘Your servants have tended livestock from our boyhood on, just as our fathers did.’ Then you will be allowed to settle in the region of Goshen, for all shepherds are detestable to the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father and brothers, with their flocks and herds and everything they own, have come from the land of Canaan and are now in Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He chose five of his brothers and presented them before Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh asked the brothers, “What is your occupation?”
“Your servants are shepherds,” they replied to Pharaoh, “just as our fathers were.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also said to him, “We have come to live here for a while, because the famine is severe in Canaan and your servants’ flocks have no pasture. So now, please let your servants settle in Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the land of Egypt is before you; settle your father and your brothers in the best part of the land. Let them live in Goshen. And if you know of any among them with special ability, put them in charge of my own livestock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph brought his father Jacob in and presented him before Pharaoh. After Jacob blessed Pharaoh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh asked him, “How old are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jacob said to Pharaoh, “The years of my pilgrimage are a hundred and thirty. My years have been few and difficult, and they do not equal the years of the pilgrimage of my fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph settled his father and his brothers in Egypt and gave them property in the best part of the land, the district of Rameses, as Pharaoh directed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph also provided his father and his brothers and all his father’s household with food, according to the number of their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no food, however, in the whole region because the famine was severe; both Egypt and Canaan wasted away because of the famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph collected all the money that was to be found in Egypt and Canaan in payment for the grain they were buying, and he brought it to Pharaoh’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the money of the people of Egypt and Canaan was gone, all Egypt came to Joseph and said, “Give us food. Why should we die before your eyes? Our money is all gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then bring your livestock,” said Joseph. “I will sell you food in exchange for your livestock, since your money is gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and he gave them food in exchange for their horses, their sheep and goats, their cattle and donkeys. And he brought them through that year with food in exchange for all their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that year was over, they came to him the following year and said, “We cannot hide from our lord the fact that since our money is gone and our livestock belongs to you, there is nothing left for our lord except our bodies and our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should we perish before your eyes—we and our land as well? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we with our land will be in bondage to Pharaoh. Give us seed so that we may live and not die, and that the land may not become desolate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph bought all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh. The Egyptians, one and all, sold their fields, because the famine was too severe for them. The land became Pharaoh’s,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Joseph reduced the people to servitude, from one end of Egypt to the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, he did not buy the land of the priests, because they received a regular allotment from Pharaoh and had food enough from the allotment Pharaoh gave them. That is why they did not sell their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to the people, “Now that I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh, here is seed for you so you can plant the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the crop comes in, give a fifth of it to Pharaoh. The other four-fifths you may keep as seed for the fields and as food for yourselves and your households and your children.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have saved our lives,” they said. “May we find favor in the eyes of our lord; we will be in bondage to Pharaoh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph established it as a law concerning land in Egypt—still in force today—that a fifth of the produce belongs to Pharaoh. It was only the land of the priests that did not become Pharaoh’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Israelites settled in Egypt in the region of Goshen. They acquired property there and were fruitful and increased greatly in number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob lived in Egypt seventeen years, and the years of his life were a hundred and forty-seven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time drew near for Israel to die, he called for his son Joseph and said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, put your hand under my thigh and promise that you will show me kindness and faithfulness. Do not bury me in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but when I rest with my fathers, carry me out of Egypt and bury me where they are buried.”
“I will do as you say,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Swear to me,” he said. Then Joseph swore to him, and Israel worshiped as he leaned on the top of his staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later Joseph was told, “Your father is ill.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim along with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph has come to you,” Israel rallied his strength and sat up on the bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and there he blessed me
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to me, ‘I am going to make you fruitful and increase your numbers. I will make you a community of peoples, and I will give this land as an everlasting possession to your descendants after you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now then, your two sons born to you in Egypt before I came to you here will be reckoned as mine; Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any children born to you after them will be yours; in the territory they inherit they will be reckoned under the names of their brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I was returning from Paddan, to my sorrow Rachel died in the land of Canaan while we were still on the way, a little distance from Ephrath. So I buried her there beside the road to Ephrath” (that is, Bethlehem).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Israel saw the sons of Joseph, he asked, “Who are these?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They are the sons God has given me here,” Joseph said to his father.
Then Israel said, “Bring them to me so I may bless them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Israel’s eyes were failing because of old age, and he could hardly see. So Joseph brought his sons close to him, and his father kissed them and embraced them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “I never expected to see your face again, and now God has allowed me to see your children too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph removed them from Israel’s knees and bowed down with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joseph took both of them, Ephraim on his right toward Israel’s left hand and Manasseh on his left toward Israel’s right hand, and brought them close to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Israel reached out his right hand and put it on Ephraim’s head, though he was the younger, and crossing his arms, he put his left hand on Manasseh’s head, even though Manasseh was the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he blessed Joseph and said,
“May the God before whom my fathers
    Abraham and Isaac walked faithfully,
the God who has been my shepherd
    all my life to this day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the Angel who has delivered me from all harm
    —may he bless these boys.
May they be called by my name
    and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac,
and may they increase greatly
    on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw his father placing his right hand on Ephraim’s head he was displeased; so he took hold of his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to him, “No, my father, this one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his father refused and said, “I know, my son, I know. He too will become a people, and he too will become great. Nevertheless, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a group of nations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He blessed them that day and said,
“In your name will Israel pronounce this blessing:
    ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.’”
So he put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel said to Joseph, “I am about to die, but God will be with you and take you back to the land of your fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And to you I give one more ridge of land than to your brothers, the ridge I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob called for his sons and said: “Gather around so I can tell you what will happen to you in days to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Assemble and listen, sons of Jacob;
    listen to your father Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Reuben, you are my firstborn,
    my might, the first sign of my strength,
    excelling in honor, excelling in power.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Simeon and Levi are brothers—
    their swords are weapons of violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let me not enter their council,
    let me not join their assembly,
for they have killed men in their anger
    and hamstrung oxen as they pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed be their anger, so fierce,
    and their fury, so cruel!
I will scatter them in Jacob
    and disperse them in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You are a lion’s cub, Judah;
    you return from the prey, my son.
Like a lion he crouches and lies down,
    like a lioness—who dares to rouse him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The scepter will not depart from Judah,
    nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet,
until he to whom it belongs shall come
    and the obedience of the nations shall be his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will tether his donkey to a vine,
    his colt to the choicest branch;
he will wash his garments in wine,
    his robes in the blood of grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes will be darker than wine,
    his teeth whiter than milk.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Issachar is a rawboned donkey
    lying down among the sheep pens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he sees how good is his resting place
    and how pleasant is his land,
he will bend his shoulder to the burden
    and submit to forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Dan will provide justice for his people
    as one of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dan will be a snake by the roadside,
    a viper along the path,
that bites the horse’s heels
    so that its rider tumbles backward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I look for your deliverance, Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Gad will be attacked by a band of raiders,
    but he will attack them at their heels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Asher’s food will be rich;
    he will provide delicacies fit for a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Naphtali is a doe set free
    that bears beautiful fawns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Joseph is a fruitful vine,
    a fruitful vine near a spring,
    whose branches climb over a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With bitterness archers attacked him;
    they shot at him with hostility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But his bow remained steady,
    his strong arms stayed limber,
because of the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob,
    because of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because of your father’s God, who helps you,
    because of the Almighty, who blesses you
with blessings of the skies above,
    blessings of the deep springs below,
    blessings of the breast and womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your father’s blessings are greater
    than the blessings of the ancient mountains,
    than the bounty of the age-old hills.
Let all these rest on the head of Joseph,
    on the brow of the prince among his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: All these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he blessed them, giving each the blessing appropriate to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gave them these instructions: “I am about to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Abraham and his wife Sarah were buried, there Isaac and his wife Rebekah were buried, and there I buried Leah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field and the cave in it were bought from the Hittites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob had finished giving instructions to his sons, he drew his feet up into the bed, breathed his last and was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph threw himself on his father and wept over him and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph directed the physicians in his service to embalm his father Israel. So the physicians embalmed him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: taking a full forty days, for that was the time required for embalming. And the Egyptians mourned for him seventy days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the days of mourning had passed, Joseph said to Pharaoh’s court, “If I have found favor in your eyes, speak to Pharaoh for me. Tell him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘My father made me swear an oath and said, “I am about to die; bury me in the tomb I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.” Now let me go up and bury my father; then I will return.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “Go up and bury your father, as he made you swear to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph went up to bury his father. All Pharaoh’s officials accompanied him—the dignitaries of his court and all the dignitaries of Egypt—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: besides all the members of Joseph’s household and his brothers and those belonging to his father’s household. Only their children and their flocks and herds were left in Goshen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chariots and horsemen also went up with him. It was a very large company.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they reached the threshing floor of Atad, near the Jordan, they lamented loudly and bitterly; and there Joseph observed a seven-day period of mourning for his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Canaanites who lived there saw the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “The Egyptians are holding a solemn ceremony of mourning.” That is why that place near the Jordan is called Abel Mizraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob’s sons did as he had commanded them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried him to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre, which Abraham had bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After burying his father, Joseph returned to Egypt, together with his brothers and all the others who had gone with him to bury his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “What if Joseph holds a grudge against us and pays us back for all the wrongs we did to him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent word to Joseph, saying, “Your father left these instructions before he died:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what you are to say to Joseph: I ask you to forgive your brothers the sins and the wrongs they committed in treating you so badly.’ Now please forgive the sins of the servants of the God of your father.” When their message came to him, Joseph wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers then came and threw themselves down before him. “We are your slaves,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joseph said to them, “Don’t be afraid. Am I in the place of God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, don’t be afraid. I will provide for you and your children.” And he reassured them and spoke kindly to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph stayed in Egypt, along with all his father’s family. He lived a hundred and ten years
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw the third generation of Ephraim’s children. Also the children of Makir son of Manasseh were placed at birth on Joseph’s knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to his brothers, “I am about to die. But God will surely come to your aid and take you up out of this land to the land he promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joseph made the Israelites swear an oath and said, “God will surely come to your aid, and then you must carry my bones up from this place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph died at the age of a hundred and ten. And after they embalmed him, he was placed in a coffin in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator
